body: The Christmas card You received today, I want you to know I mailed last May.LOUIS PHILLIPS SOON it will be time to put on funny hats and blow kazoos, time to eat fish eggs and raise a glass to 1984. Right now we must do something about these Christmas leftovers in the mailbag. On the top of the heap sits a dispatch from the bank line, never a good
title: METROPOLITAN DIARY

body: The Talk of Ridgewood Joannene Coppinger, born and raised in the neighborhood, lives 15 blocks from her parents, who live half a block from her grandmother, a Ridgewood resident since 1912. Ted Renz has a house 10 blocks from his parents' apartment, above their knitting mill. For 33 years, Angie Tantillo, who was a Richmond Hill girl until she
title: THE TALK OF RIDGEWOOD; RIDGEWOOD GAINS RECOGNITION AND QUICHE MAY JOIN THE STRUDEL

body: IN New York, there is a Christmas less obvious than the window displays along Fifth Avenue, the Christmas tree in Rockefeller Center and the tree under the arch in Washington Square. But, New York's hidden Christmas, unlike that in many cities, is not only the sum total of many small, personal expressions - like the tinsel wrapped around a trash
title: CITY SIGHTS: HOLIDAY SURPRISES WORTH LOOKING FOR

body: FROM the churches to the concert hall and the stage, from the streets and the parks to the lobbies of the city's office buildings, New York offers distinctly urban settings for Christmas music. The city might not have the snowy fields, jingling sleighs or carolers on the lawn of a Currier and Ives scene, but it compensates, as it does in every
title: HEAR THE SOUNDS OF CHRISTMAS

body: John Langstaff declares that ''The Christmas Revels'' program of song, dance and music he is presenting this weekend for the fourth year at the Symphony Space, Broadway and 95th Street, will be uplifting, joyous and spiritual without being religious and celebratory. The ''Revels'' are not celebrating the holiday but the season, Mr. Langstaff said
title: 'REVELS' SALUTES THE WINTER SOLSTICE

body: MOST dedicated cooks are, by nature, exceedingly acquisitive types, forever on the prowl for unusual foods, new utensils and elegant serving pieces and accessories to enhance the presentation of their creations. This makes Christmas shopping for food lovers a relatively easy task, assuming you are well attuned to the recipient's tastes and styles.
title: CHRISTMAS GIFTS FOR COOKS AND CONNOISSEURS

body: FOLLOWING the clearance of a backlog of applications, 69 areas of New York City are now listed on the Federal and State Historic Registers. Unlike landmark designation by the city, which imposes restraints on facade alterations, the state and national listings impose no restrictions on privately sponsored projects. Lengthy review is necessary,
title: 69 CITY DISTRICTS DUBBED HISTORIC

body: To release hardened criminals when we have been seeking relief from the crime rate is outrage enough without having it compounded by creation of jail space on the doorstep of long-awaited redevelopment projects. - Howard Golden, Brooklyn Borough President When prisoners must be released from crowded jails, what's a good politician to do? Denounce
title: A True Jail Outrage

body: Tuneful Gossip in Brooklyn Madrigals were a substitute for newspapers in the Middle Ages, a form of gossip as minstrels traveled from court to court. Tomorrow at the First Unitarian Church on Pierrepont Street in Brooklyn Heights, the West Side Madrigalists will perform music sung in New York ''from our forefathers to the present,'' said Judith
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

body: The low-rise condominium market is thriving in a western corner of Staten Island known as Graniteville. Only 10 years ago, the area - north of the Staten Island Expressway about a mile from the Goethals Bridge - was a flat and rather barren urban outback. The expressway has been changing that. The trip by express bus to lower Manhattan from the
title: ABOUT REAL ESTATE; NEW CONDOMINIUMS ARE ON THE RISE IN STATEN ISLAND

body: The mourning for Anne Pfreundschuh, the period of public grief, lasted three long days. On Thursday, Nov. 10, two days after she was found slain, 500 classmates at the Pratt Institute in Brooklyn marched in the rain and gathered for a silent vigil. On Friday they returned for a memorial service a few blocks from the campus. And the next morning, in
title: Murder of Well-Liked Senior Leaves Pratt Campus Shaken

body: AFTER years of camping out in the city, living in that awful one room, making do with second-rate furniture, eating from dishes that don't match, all the while waiting for Mr. Right to appear and take them away from all this, single women in their 30's and 40's are beginning to feather their solitary nests in a style that would have been
title: TODAY THE SINGLE WOMAN IS SETTING UP HOUSE IN STYLE

body: William Everdell was sketching the outlines of West Germany on a chalkboard in a classroom at St. Ann's School in Brooklyn Heights, talking to his students about the Pershing 2 missiles to be deployed in that country starting next month. ''The Russians are very concerned about the Germans,'' Mr. Everdell said. ''They have been invaded by the
title: CLASSES ON NUCLEAR WAR MOVE INTO CURRICULUMS

body: IF an athlete was ranked second in the United States as well as the North American championship, was a member of the team that won a gold medal at the Pan American Games this year and had, furthermore, represented the United States in four world championship tournaments, no one could be blamed for considering her great. title: LONG ISLANDERS; A WINNER'S OTHER GOALS

Ashley of Brooklyn Heights. The Rev. John M. McConnell performed the ceremony at St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in New York. Mari Margaret
title: Kathleen Ann Monahan Is the Bride Of Chase Whitcher Ashley, a Lawyer

body: One of the most appealing of New York's instrumental groups, the Jupiter Symphony, begins its fifth season Sunday afternoon with a special concert in Harlem. The Jupiter, conducted by Jens Nygaard, the group's music director and one of its founders, will appear at St. Martin's Church at Lenox Avenue and 122d Street in Harlem. There will be music by
title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES

body: It seemed like an incredible statement, coming as it did from a man about to command a $150,000-a-year salary: Robert R. Kiley, the chairman-designate of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, said shortly after he was nominated that his family probably could not afford to live in Manhattan and that he would look for a house in Brooklyn Heights
title: THE HIGH PRICE OF BROOKLYN HTS.

body: Transit's Bad Old Days ''We found in doing research for this exhibition that things in the good old days were not necessarily so good,'' said David M. Kahn, executive director of the Long Island Historical Society, a fixture in Brooklyn Heights since 1863. He was talking about the society's show called ''In Transit: Two Centuries of Commuting in
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

body: Dr. Rita Guttman, a biophysicist and a former professor of biology at Brooklyn College, died of a cerebral hemorrhage Oct. 12 at the Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 71 years old and lived in Brooklyn Heights. Dr. Guttman joined Brooklyn College in 1936 and retired in 1978. In 1967 she was the first woman to be elected to the Council of the
title: DR. RITA GUTTMAN

Congdon of Brooklyn Heights. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. William O'Brien at St. Michael's Episcopal Church. Judith B. Grimes was maid of honor and Alexander H. Stanton was
title: Michael Congdon Wed To Margaret Herrity

body: THE BALI WAY Before performing classical dance from their native Bali at the Asia Society this afternoon, Suarni and Suarti, who are sisters, will demonstrate its basic patterns and movements. The young women mastered them in training that began at the ages of 3 or 4, when their grandmother, a dancer in Bali, stood behind them, placing their hands
title: GOING OUT GUIDE

body: New York's subway riders can expect two to three years of ''frustration'' as major work on rebuilding the system gets under way, Robert R. Kiley, the chairman-designate of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, said today. ''Users of the subway in New York City are facing very difficult circumstances, more than any others in the country,'' Mr.
title: 2 TROUBLED YEARS ON SUBWAYS SEEN BY M.T.A. NOMINEE

Bowe of Stratford, Conn., and the late Francis P. Bowe. A June wedding is planned. Miss Langstaff graduated from the Putney (Vt.) School and Connecticut College. She is a

body: I Love New York And L.A., Too As an Angeleno who has been living in New York for the past three years, I have often been asked to account for the differences in the New York and Los Angeles ''personalities'' (''I Love New York and L.A., Too,'' by Joseph Giovannini, Sept. 11). In response, I have usually resorted to certain vagaries about the
title: No Headline

The Rev. Carl Gillmeister, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the Plaza Hotel. The bride, who is creative manager of packaging design
title: Rayne Allyn Draffin and Jeffrey Mayer Are Wed

body: Friday MORRISTOWN CRAFTS Fantastical objects, including an oversize dragonfly of satin, velvet and chiffon, and practical items, including brooms, are among the works of 135 artisans from all over the country that were chosen from those of more than 1,100 applicants to be on view and on sale tonight through Sunday in the Morristown (N.J.) title: WEEKENDER GUIDE

title: For Children; Music, Plays, Shows

body: For all of its 10 years, the New York Landmarks Conservancy, a nonprofit group dedicated to the preservation of noteworthy buildings, has had to ''beg, beg, beg, day after day'' simply to stay in business, according to its chairman, Brendan Gill. Now it faces a different problem - how to spend $500,000 that has come its way through a failed effort
title: LANDMARK GROUP PLANS USES FOR BILTMORE FUNDS

body: ''ENNIALS'' This has been a big New York year for ''ennials,'' the centennial anniversaries of the Brooklyn Bridge and the Metropolitan Opera, the bicentennial anniversaries of the American peace treaty with Great Britain, the British evacuation of New York City and the birth of the statesman and author Washington Irving. The New York Public
title: GOING OUT GUIDE;

body: FOR years Cobble Hill was called a poor man's Brooklyn Heights. But no longer. ''Not when you've got houses selling for $425,000,'' said Penelope Karagias, a local real-estate broker. ''That's not remotely the case anymore.'' Cobble Hill, a 22-block area south of Brooklyn Heights bordered by Atlantic Avenue and Hicks, DeGraw and Court Streets, has
title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: COBBLE HILL

body: George Washington stayed in the neighborhood, and so did Thomas Wolfe in the 1930's, when he wrote that only the dead know Brooklyn. Jennie Jerome, the mother of Winston Churchill, was born there in 1854. It lies due south of Brooklyn Heights, across the teeming Atlantic Avenue border of Middle Eastern restaurants and food shops. In the words of
title: A STROLL THROUGH COBBLE HILL'S STREETS AND HOMES

title: Catherine G. Roberts and Piero Casalicchio Marry

title: Daniela Wittman Is Married to Richard L. Amdur

body: VICTORIA FELDMAN had hoped for her own bedroom, but she shares a studio apartment and sleeps on a sofa bed. Robin Kaplan had planned to be independent, but instead she takes money from her parents each month to help pay her rent. Robert Cohen would have liked to live in Manhattan, but the prices drove him first to Queens, then to Brooklyn and, just
title: FIRST JOB, FIRST SEARCH FOR A CITY APARTMENT

body: ''A sign of the times,'' observes Sol Zatt, who was riding in a cab in Manhattan when an urgent message came over the radio: ''No. 18, call your broker.'' title: METROPOLITAN DIARY

body: DAVID Booth makes it look easy. Once a successful investment consultant with the Wall Street firm of A. G. Becker, Paribas Inc., he left in 1981 and set up his own office in the second bedroom of his brownstone apartment in Brooklyn Heights. Business seemed to fall in his lap: In only 18 months, his firm, Dimensional Fund Advisors, has landed 48
title: PERILS AND PROFITS OF PENSION ADVISERS

body: WALKING tours of New York have come a long way since 10 years ago, when such institutions as the Municipal Art Society, the Museum of the City of New York and the Friends of Cast Iron Architecture began to take New Yorkers on ordered routes through the city's history and architecture. Today, it is possible to spend almost any weekend scrutinizing
title: NEW YORK'S SIDEWALKS: A CHOICE OF TOURS

Cantor Richard H. Berman performed the ceremony at the couple's home in Brooklyn Heights. The bride, an alumna of the Bishop's Schools in La
title: R. S. Harrison Weds Jolie Ann Bales

body: To the Editor: In endorsing the present structure of New York City's Board of Estimate, The Times has focused (most recently in an Aug. 21 editorial) on Staten Island's threat to secede from the city as a result of a Federal court ruling that the Board of Estimate must comply with one-person, one- vote requirements. You have sympathized with Staten
title: A STATEN ISLAND SOLUTION FIT FOR ALL OF NEW YORK

body: At St. Stephen's Lutheran Church in Wilmington, Del., yesterday, Dr. Janot June Bente and Dr. Stuart Edward Lieblich, graduates of the University of Pennsylvania School of Dental Medicine, were married by the Rev. Norman Thiess. The bride, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul F. Bente Jr. of Bethesda, Md., graduated also from the University of Delaware
title: Dr. Janot Bente Is Married To Dr. Stuart E. Lieblich

body: Getting Away From It All: Miss Bellamy's Route In training for her first assault on the Appalachian Trail, which begins today, City Council President Carol Bellamy has been dragging around Brooklyn Heights for the last few weeks in her hiking boots with a 40- pound backpack. ''I'm going to do the first 120 miles,'' Miss Bellamy said yesterday,
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

body: MANY brownstone gardens are both an asset and a problem: they promise to bring outdoor space into the lives of nature-starved New Yorkers, but the spaces themselves are usually small and sometimes damp, and they often lack light and privacy. The high canopies of the aspiring ailanthus and other city trees compound both the promise and the problem
title: SUCCESSFUL DESIGN SOLUTIONS FOR BROWNSTONE GARDENS

body: This summer's hottest performers? Arguably, the Three Bears, in bear suits, doing ''Goldilocks'' at the Penny Bridge Players, the Brooklyn Heights theater for children at 59 Cranberry Street. Its ''parking lot'' is full of strollers. Even some older patrons (a Norman Mailer child, an Arthur Miller grandchild) come with a parent or nanny. But Penny
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY; Goldilocks Finds A Home in Brooklyn

body: Putting aside a longstanding aversion to winning adherents, Jewish leaders across the spectrum of Judaism have been working to kindle an active interest in the religion among uncommitted Jews. Jewish leaders in the Reform, Conservative and Orthodox branches said they had been acting in response to what they see as an alarming erosion of Jewish
title: JEWISH LEADERS STRIVE TO ROUSE THE UNCOMMITTED

body: ''THE SHAPES OF THINGS,'' at the 22 Wooster Gallery, 22 Wooster Street, is a group painting and drawing show that suggests how the shapes of faces, furniture, buildings - everything in the world around us - can be experienced and known through paint. There is a long tradition of this kind of patient exploration, which, at best, reveals something
title: ART: A SHOW OF SHAPES IN PAINTING AND DRAWING

body: Does the Department of Sanitation encourage New Yorkers to violate the law? Helene MacLean of Brooklyn Heights thinks so. For years she has been trying to get the department to leash the pup on its ''Clean Up After Your Dog'' sign. ''When that sign appeared all over the city,'' she said yesterday, ''I called Sanitation about the dog not wearing a
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY; New York Led Astray

body: A 45-year-old man, Antonio Yanegas, was killed, and 24 people, including 16 firefighters, were injured in a Washington Heights fire that started at 11:30 P.M. on Monday and was not brought under control until 1 A.M. yesterday. The blaze, which heavily damaged a six-story apartment building at 2185 Amsterdam Avenue, near 168th Street, was declared
title: THE CITY; The Police Blotter

body: FROM THE FRENCH Perhaps not even in France has French film gotten the scrutiny that it is undergoing at the Museum of Modern Art, 18 West 54th Street, where Gallic movies have been unreeling since November 1981 as part of the series ''Rediscovering French Film.'' Part I, a shorter package, ran from November 1981 to January 1982. Part II started
title: GOING OUT GUIDE;

body: Three Americans have won prizes in the 11th International Ballet Competition in Varna, Bulgaria. Katherine Healy, 14 years old, of Bryn Mawr, Pa., was awarded a first prize in the junior division. Bonnie Moore, 18, of Phoenix won a junior third prize, and Maria Teresa Del Real, 20, of Miami won a third prize in the senior division. The contest's
title: 3 AMERICANS ARE WINNERS IN INTERNATIONAL BALLET COMPETITION

body: SINOPHILES can be forgiven if they do not recognize the starkly modish black-and-white setting of Auntie Yuan as a place to dine on Cantonese food. If it weren't for the chopsticks on the beige tablecloths set with Wedgwood drabware, the black Fitz & Floyd plates with pink flowers and the simulated bone-handled silverware, these stunning
title: RESTAURANTS; Cantonese dining in a modish setting.

body: ANALIA It may be mostly Mozart in Manhattan but it's altogether Bach in Brooklyn, where the third annual Brooklyn Bach Festival opens at 8 o'clock tonight in the Chapel of the First Unitarian Church, Monroe Place at Pierrepont Avenue, in Brooklyn Heights. That lovely neighborhood also is near gracious refreshment before or after the concert: Arabic
title: GOING OUT GUIDE

body: Anne Hewlett Fuller, the widow of the futurist, inventor and architect R. Buckminster Fuller, died early yesterday morning at Good Samaritan Hospital in Los Angeles, just 36 hours after her husband's death. Mr. Fuller, the creator of the geodesic dome, was stricken with a fatal heart attack late Friday while visiting the bedside of his wife of 65
title: ANNE HEWLETT FULLER, 87, DIES; WIDOW OF FUTURIST ARCHITECT

body: WITH temperatures high, tempers have been rising in some historic districts in Manhattan as residents have learned that they are not permitted to install air-conditioners through the walls of their apartments without permission from the Landmarks Preservation Commission. Under regulations that were intended to preserve the architectural integrity
title: ON AIR-CONDITIONERS IN LANDMARK AREAS

body: Brooklyn Sesquicentennial I t's 50 years older than the Brooklyn Bridge. Even its honorary historian, Francis E. Walton, is seven days older than the bridge. But Brookwood Child Care, founded as the Orphan Asylum Society of the City of Brooklyn, passed its sesquicentennial last month in the shadow of the bridge celebration. A yearlong ''double
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

title: Ann Marcus and a Teacher Are Married on Fire Island

The program has helped to extend the market in for-sale housing to sections of the city where previously it
title: PERSPECTIVES: CONVERSIONS; LEFRAK CO-OPS EXTENDING MARKET RANGE

body: If I were asked to define the difference between house restoration and renovation,'' Dr. Theodore Lindauer says, ''I would say $100,000.'' Dr. Lindauer, a Los Angeles psychiatrist, knows the distinction well. He recently completed six years of work restoring the Edwards House, an International style classic in the Los Angeles hills designed by the
title: MAKING HOUSES FROM THE PAST FIT THE PRESENT

body: Dr. and Mrs. Howard Haldeman Steel of Villanova, Pa., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Steel's daughter, Celia Ellan Smith, to Brian Winstanley Carroll, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Patrick Carroll Jr. of New York. Miss Smith is a daughter also of Dr. Edward Cary Smith of Spokane, Wash. An Aug. 27 wedding is planned. Miss Smith, a writer
title: Celia Smith Is Betrothed

body: In neighborhoods throughout the city and across a broad spectrum of New York life, the influence of homosexual men and women is being seen and felt more than ever before. The yearly Gay Pride March, scheduled for June 26, is only one sign of the broadened awareness of homosexuality and the changes it has brought over the last decade and a half. The
title: HOMOSEXUALS CONFRONTING A TIME OF CHANGE

body: LORI LECKMAN remembers vividly the sights and scents in the Los Angeles bakery where she worked one summer vacation while in high school. ''I served customers up front and later helped out in the back,'' she recalls. ''But the chef never let me touch the ovens. He told me that women could never be bakers - too tough for them.'' Today, 29-year-old
title: PASTRY CHEFS WHO BREACH A MALE BASTION

body: With 90-degree temperatures signaling the onset of outdoor activity for thousands of New Yorkers, two of the city's most visible problems -festering piles of curb-side garbage and large numbers of illegal street peddlers - are back again like the shimmering heat waves of summer. What happened to the city's recent crackdown on peddlers? Why do the
title: TWO PLAGUES THAT WILL NOT GO AWAY

The chairman, Margaret Bush Wilson, said in an interview yesterday in The St. Louis Post-Dispatch that the behavior of the
title: OUSTER AT N.A.A.C.P. IS LAID TO 'BIZARRE BEHAVIOR'

body: WHAT'S the Celebrity Capital of the United States? Some say New York, some say Los Angeles. The debate took a new turn recently when the Greenland brothers - Drew of New York and Seth of Los Angeles - squared off in a contest of random celebrity sightings. It was agreed that whoever came up with the greater number of famous faces over a period of
title: METROPOLITAN DIARY

body: BARBARA LABINE went home last week, back home to Brooklyn. She had never been there before, but as soon as she felt Brooklyn Dodger fans of all ages reaching out to her and her husband, Clem, she knew she was home. ''Like an Italian family,'' said Barbara Labine, who knows about Italian families, having grown up in one. Her new ties are with a
title: Remembering The Dodgers

body: A majority of board members of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People called yesterday for the resignation of the association's chairman, Margaret Bush Wilson, and voted to curb her powers sharply. A telegram requesting the resignation was authorized by 48 of the N.A.A.C.P.'s 64 board members and was sent to Mrs. Wilson in
title: BOARD OF N.A.A.C.P. CALLS FOR RESIGNATION OF UNIT'S CHAIRMAN

body: AFTER hardly any spring, summer arrives today - if not on the calendar, then at least by custom. To greet the season ushered in by the Memorial Day holiday, New Yorkers and their neighbors have a wide choice of outdoor things to do this weekend. These range in exertion from lying down - the beaches open tomorrow - to pedaling around Central Park in
title: GETTING THE JUMP ON SUMMER OUTDOORS

body: In front of a house on Lafayette Avenue in Bedford-Stuyvesant stands a magnolia tree as big as a brownstone, its broad leaves as glossy as if each had been individually oiled. It is a magnolia grandiflora, and it usually grows nowhere north of the Mason-Dixon line. Somehow, improbably, with considerable help from human beings, this tree grows in
title: ABOUT NEW YORK; CITY OR BOROUGH, DODGERS OR NO DODGERS, BROOKLYN IS BROOKLYN

body: With an unabashed outpouring of affection, New York celebrated the 100th anniversary of the Brooklyn Bridge yesterday. It had been billed as a great day in the history of the city, and that is exactly what it turned out to be. In the morning, thousands of pedestrians, horse-drawn carriages and marching bands - filling the air with martial music -
title: AN OLD BRIDGE'S BIRTHDAY IS A HOMETOWN CARNIVAL

body: Malcolm S. Forbes, the magazine publisher, organized a boating party to get a good view of the fireworks. Robert L. Hess, the president of Brooklyn College, looked out at the borough - and the bridge - of his heart from a 60th-floor soiree in Manhattan. William R. Everdell, a Brooklyn historian, decided to celebrate by sending out for pizza. Much
title: FROM A PIZZA BY LAND TO FILLET OF BEEF BY SEA

body: It was the Brooklyn Bridge in music. Beneath the Roeblings' stone towers, an orchestra played into the night, offering a vigorous serenade to the skyscrapers of Manhattan and the town houses of Brooklyn Heights. The orchestra was the Brooklyn Philharmonic; Paul Dunkel was conducting, and the composer, Tobias Picker, was at the piano. Mr. Picker's
title: A CONCERTO TO THE BEAT OF THE CITY

body: Margaret Bush Wilson, chairman of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said yesterday that she was ''unaware of any constitutionally called meeting'' planned by other members of the board to discuss her suspension of Benjamin L. Hooks as executive director of the organization last week. Some dissident members of he
title: CHAIRMAN OF N.A.A.C.P. SAYS SHE IS 'UNAWARE' OF MEETING

body: The Brooklyn Bridge, one of the city's best-loved landmarks, will be 100 years old tomorrow, and a big birthday party is planned. A parade of 18,000 will cross the grand old bridge on foot, on horse, in carriages, on floats, in historic buses, by horse-drawn ambulance and horse-drawn pumper, in a Model T Ford and even atop a small elephant. They
title: PARADES, FIREWORKS AND MUSIC TO MARK DAY

body: There is nothing like a celebration to work up an appetite, and if there is any one frustration that tomorrow's merrymakers can expect to confront in their pursuit of nourishment, it is choice. The Brooklyn Bridge is in the hub of one of the great gourmet centers of the world - the crossroads between Little Italy and Chinatown on the north, TriBeCa
title: WIDE CHOICE FOR HUNGRY CELEBRATORS

body: At St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church yesterday, Mary Young Pommerich and Stephen Joseph Conway were married by the Rev. Thomas Splain. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Glenn Henry Pommerich of Oakfield, Wis. Her husband is the son of Joseph A. Conway of Truro, Mass., formerly of Katonah, N.Y., and the late Elizabeth Hennion Conway.
title: Mary Pommerich Wed To Stephen J. Conway

body: It is tempting to say that there has not been a first-class public open space created in Manhattan since Central Park. It would not be true, of course - there is Paley Park, and the promenade over the East River Drive at Carl Schurz Park, and the sculpture garden of the Museum of Modern Art. But the list of decent open spaces is short - so short
title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW; AT LAST, A WELCOME PUBLIC SPACE FOR MANHATTAN

body: Benjamin L. Hooks has been indefinitely suspended as executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People by the organization's chairman, Margaret Bush Wilson, members of the association's board said yesterday. Mrs. Wilson, who has long been in a power struggle with Mr. Hooks, formally suspended him on Wednesday, A
title: N.A.A.C.P. OFFICIALS SAY DIRECTOR HAS BEEN INDEFINITELY SUSPENDED

body: To Rita Schwartz there seemed nothing strange about leaving a city-sponsored meeting to dash off to a morning musicale in a Brooklyn Heights home. ''This is another world - you simply don't know that anything like it exists in the middle of New York,'' said Mrs. Schwartz, who has held several positions in city government. ''It is like going back to
title: NEIGHBORS MAKE MUSIC A WEDNESDAY TRADITION

body: From Old York to New T he glow inside the Episcopal Church of St. Ann and the Holy Trinity in Brooklyn Heights comes from 60 jewel-like windows, in tones of garnet, sapphire and emerald. Completed in 1847, as the first stained-glass church windows in America, they were the work of William Jay Bolton and John Bolton, the British-born sons of a
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

body: IT WAS, said Salvadore Scotto, a surprise. In the early 1960's, the b rownstoners began to trickle in, first into Cobble Hill, across A tlantic Avenue from Brooklyn Heights, and then farther south into h is neighborhood, an Italian enclave that had its own identity but n ot a name, a place that some called South Brooklyn and others simply' 'the
title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: CARROLL GARDENS

body: THE GREAT EAST RIVER BRIDGE 1883-1983. Preface by Williard C. Butcher. Foreword by Michael Botwinick and Linda S. Ferber. Essays by Deborah Nevins, Barbara Head Millstein, David McCullough, Albert Fein, Lewis Kachur, Steven S. Ross. 180 Pages. Published by the Brooklyn Museum and Harry N. Abrams. $35. ''O harp and altar, of the fury fused.''
title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; The Brooklyn Bridge

body: OPERA NOTES Verdi wrote '' Aida'' for the opening of the Suez Canal, but, in the lack of a similar opening work for the debut of the Brooklyn Bridge 100 years ago, the Brooklyn Opera Society is presenting Gounod's ''Faust'' tonight and Saturday, in Brooklyn, of course. Tonight at 8 o'clock, this ambitious production fills the Kingsborough Community
title: GOING OUT GUIDE

title: Mary Neroda Affianced

body: LEG STRETCHING The weekends have not been entirely what they should be in the way of heartwarming sunshine, but the calendar counts off, inexorably, and we are deep into spring. Whatever nature decrees, the return of spring is attested, more surely than the arrival of the first swallow, by the resumption of the Sunday walking tours of the Museum of
title: GOING OUT GUIDE

body: IF preservation in Brooklyn Heights begins in the home, the dominant image here is not the single, splendid house, but one of streets flanked by rows of brownstones. These are buildings that are enormously cooperative in establishing a protective feeling, a human scale, great architectural variety within an overall continuity, and a certain
title: IN BROOKLYN HEIGHTS THE ELEGANT ART OF PRESERVATION

body: The Brooklyn Heights house tour will be held on May 14 from 1 to 4 P.M. The antiques show will start on Thursday night, May 12, with a preview reception from 6:30 to 9 P.M., and will run through Saturday. House tour tickets are available, on an advance sale basis only, for $15, and include admission to the antiques show and tea in the church
title: ANTIQUES SHOW AND TOUR

Murrow High School, he ''used to go with friends to talk'' in the graveyard, which is part of Washington Cemetery. Now Mr. Colman, with his one-act play ''Third Street'' - which features the graveyard -
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY; Young Playwrights

body: David McCullough, whose most recent book is ''Mornings on Horseback,'' a biography of Theodore Roosevelt, also wrote ''The Great Bridge.'' title: THE GREAT BRIDGE AND THE AMERICAN IMAGINATION

title: EXECUTIVES ARE OFFERED A CITY GUIDE TO HOUSING

body: Social scientists believe that the level of public tolerance of the use of illegal drugs is continuing to rise in all levels of American society. They say, further, that the growing availability and acceptability of these drugs is effecting profound social changes that have neither been fully acknowledged nor fully understood. The signs of the
title: U.S. SOCIAL TOLERANCE OF DRUGS FOUND ON RISE

body: Sandstone and brownstone buildings decay easily - the surface may rub off, large sections of stone may separate and be lost or the facade may become cracked or blistered. These problems are addressed in a new eight-page pamphlet, ''The Maintenance and Repair of Architectural Sandstone,'' prepared by the New York Landmarks Conservancy. The
title: SANDSTONE FACADES : A GUIDE TO REPAIRS

body: On the Friday before last, an orange typing-paper box arrived unannounced at the offices of the Scott Meredith literary agency in New York, its delivery an act of friendship by Norman Mailer. In it were 300 pages of a first novel by an aspiring writer named Richard Lowell Stratton, who has been working on the book in his cell here in the Cumberland
title: WRITER OF BOOK ON DRUGS ON TRIAL FOR SMUGGLING

body: Brooklyn Heights With Sound and Lights C annon shots are heard lately in Brooklyn Heights. Residents see mysterious banks of lights go on outside the First Unitarian Church, Pierrepont Street and Monroe Place. It's all part of a son et lumiere show, ''To Build on the Heights,'' celebrating the church's 150th anniversary. On Thursdays, Fridays and
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

body: Brooklyn Jumps the Gun On Honoring Its Women L ady Deborah Moody laid out the Gravesend section of Brooklyn in the 1640's in four squares, still apparent through the modern grid. Margaret Sanger's first clinic was in Brownsville until the police jailed her. Mary White Ovington, a society heiress, did social work in Greenpoint and Williamsburg.
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

title: Ann M. Jacobs Is Wed To Frederick J. Bruce

body: The mezzo-soprano Frederica von Stade will not appear with the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center for three concerts, because of a death in her family. title: Miss von Stade Drops Chamber Society Dates

title: HIGH DEMAND BUOYS MARKET FOR CO-OPS

body: For many contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, the nation's economic situation - with high unemployment, inflation and cutbacks in social services - appears to be the primary cause of the human suffering they see around them. With a contribution of $1,000 to the fund's 71st annual appeal, Mrs. Harvey J. Amsterdam of Oyster Bay,
title: HARDSHIP LINKED TO ECONOMY SPURS GIFTS TO NEEDIEST CASES

body: MUCH has been said about the so-called Supermom, the woman who tries to juggle a career with a family. As Supermom struggles to do it all, another group of women have come to the conclusion that the pressures of this dual role can often cause them to be mediocre at both. So they have given up their careers to stay home with their children. ''It
title: MOTHERS WHO SHIFT BACK FROM JOBS TO HOMEMAKING

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

body: WITH more than 17,000 landmark buildings and 42 historic districts t o protect, policing New York City's architectural resources can be ad aunting task. For the Landmarks Preservation Commission, a staff of 5 0 full-time members often proves insufficient. Nearly all of those districts, however -and even some areas that have not been designated
title: VOLUNTEERS WHO SERVE HISTORY

body: THERE is something that the Metropolitan Museum of Art shares with the New York Yacht Club, the Dutch Reformed Church on Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn, St. David's School on East 89th Street, the Appellate Division Courthouse on Madison Avenue at 25th Street, the headquarters of the Columbia School of Journalism, the Players Club on Gramercy Park
title: STAINED GLASS CASTS ITS GLOW OVER THE CITY

body: DUSK TO DAWN New York is the stay-up-late town of America, a town that may not stay up as much as it used to but which still has people, many of them, who start to come alive after sunset. Photographers rank high in the ranks of nocturnal citizens and some of what their lenses have caught in a half century is on exhibition at City Gallery, the
title: GOING OUT GUIDE

body: Following are the scores, released by the New York City Board of Education, on the reading tests given in city's public elementary schools and junior high schools in April 1982. The center column shows the proportion of pupils in each school reading at or above grade level; the right-hand column gives each school's overall city-wide ranking.
title: Scores on Reading Tests Given in Public Schools

body: Federal and city investigators said yesterday that a Puerto Rican terrorist group was apparently responsible for a series of bombings on New Year's Eve that rocked four government buildings in lower Manhattan and Brooklyn and seriously injured three police officers. The blasts, which struck Police Headquarters and two Federal office buildings in
title: F.A.L.N. PUERTO RICAN TERRORISTS SUSPECTED IN NEW YEAR BOMBINGS

body: Dr. Thomas Chiu makes psychiatric house calls on the elderly in Brooklyn. He interrupts their loneliness in apartments in city housing projects to listen to their complaints and fears. He talks to homeless and alienated women loaded down with shopping bags at the entrances to subway stations and offers them care on the spot. And if an elderly
title: PSYCHIATRIST MINISTERS TO ELDERLY POOR AT THEIR HOMES

body: There is a long tradition of classical music inspired by jazz. Milhaud, Ravel, Stravinsky, serious composers all, have found inspiration and revitalization in popular forms. But this crossfertilization can work both ways, and there are several examples of popular composers who made successful excursions into classical music. George Gershwin is one
title: MUSIC; CHICK COREA IS THINKING A LOT ABOUT MOZART NOW
